pageContext.claim: “I don't know if you noticed, but deficits seem to be coming down. And last month it was reported, and everybody was surprised, but I wasn't surprised.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump misleadingly appears to be referring to the fact that the monthly budget deficit fell from November to December. But federal revenue often fluctuates from month to month, and so there was little surprise. More to the point, annual budget deficits are rising, largely because of the tax cuts enacted by Trump. In fact, the deficit in the first three months of fiscal year 2019 was 42 percent higher than it was for the same period the year before.
